Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Growth, Mortality, and Competition of Tropical Tree and Liana Species During an Extended Drought
Award.AbstractNarration:
A major goal in ecology is to understand why different types of plants and animals occur where they do. This question is particularly important for tropical forests because they are home to most of the world's species and are essential for global carbon and nutrient cycles; they help control the atmosphere of the entire planet. In a sense, tropical plants are the "lungs" of the planet. Scientists are starting to think that drought is critically important in determining how well tropical forests "breathe". However, the evidence for this is still unclear. In this project, researchers will test how different tropical plant species respond to an ongoing, multi-year drought in Panama. Undergraduate and graduate students from the U.S. will participate in the project and receive training in how to conduct scientific research.

In the context of a large-scale, long-term competition experiment, the PI will examine the role of a multi-year drought to test two predictions: 1) The strength of plant-plant competition increases with drought and varies with species identity. 2) Plant species that capitalize on drought will share a suite of plant hydraulic functional traits. By testing these predictions, the PI can provide a functional-mechanistic explanation for how different species respond to drought, and determine whether plant-plant competition intensifies the effects of drought. By examining the responses of more than 100 plant species and by relating those responses to a suite of functional characteristics for each species, this project will identify the subset of species that will likely increase or decrease with future droughts, as well as the dual effects of drought and competition on tree species performance. Considering the importance of both drought and competition to tropical forest diversity and function, results will be fundamental to our understanding of tropical forest ecology and, more generally, ecosystem health.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Like most ecosystems around the world, tropical forests are now experiencing large-scale changes. The tropics are experiencing increasingly severe and frequent drought, which can reduce species diversity, change plant community composition, and alter tropical forest functioning. Another major change in tropical forests is the reshuffling of plant dominance. Some tropical species are increasing in abundance while others are decreasing. For example, lianas (woody vines) are increasing in abundance relative to trees. There are now 15 studies that show that liana abundance is now increasing relative to trees in tropical forests. The increase in liana abundance is alarming because lianas substantially reduce tree recruitment, growth, reproduction, survival, and diversity, as well as change key functional services of tropical forests, such as carbon uptake and storage. Despite the profound potential ramifications of large-scale changes in tropical forests, the effects of increasing drought and lianas on the rest of the forest community remain poorly understood.

The forest on the Barro Colorado Nature Monument in Panama is currently experiencing a strong, multi-year drought. In 2017, this region experienced one of the driest years on record (the 6th driest including El Niño years), and the second driest 5-year period in more than 90 years. The main goal of this NSF-funded study was to test the role of a multi-year drought combined with the effect of lianas on tree performance (growth and mortality) to test whether the strength of plant-plant competition increases with drought and varies with species identity. The current multi-year drought provided an unprecedented opportunity to study the individual and combined effects of drought and liana competition on tropical tree and liana demography at the species and functional levels. Knowledge from this study is critical to understand how tropical forests will respond to a changing climate.

We surveyed a large-scale, long-term liana-removal experiment in the Republic of Panama. By resurveying more than 30,000 trees that are part of our liana removal experiment, we were able to quantify plant growth during the drought years (2014-2018) and compare them to their growth during the non-drought (2011 – 2014) years. These data will allow us to quantify the species that perform well during drought, as well as effects of lianas on trees (growth and mortality) at both the species-specific and functional levels. We also collected measurements on different plant hydraulic traits for more than 30 liana species – hydraulic traits give insights into how plants perform during drought. By relating our newly collected plant hydraulic functional trait database to the performance of these plant species during drought (2014-2018) and non-drought (2011-2014) periods, we can determine a functional basis for species-specific performance during drought, and formulate predictions for the species that will likely benefit from increasing future drought.

This was a 1-year study, which was enough time for us to conduct the large survey data and to collect functional trait measurements. Nonetheless, during this year we were able to assemble a complete database on tree performance with and without lianas during drought (2014-2018) and non-drought (2011-2014) periods. We have also collected functional trait data from more than 30 liana species with multiple replicate individuals per species. Once we have this database finalized we will be able to start analyzing the data to address our main questions about how lianas and drought affect tree performance and growth, as well as how differences in liana traits are tied to their performance during drought. In addition to accomplishing the research goals that we stated at the onset of the study, this project has led to research opportunities and training of two female field technicians, one graduate student, and four undergraduate students from Marquette University.
